content.description: Keith bolted this one but I got the first lead. He belayed me on it so it wasn't like I stole it. When the train rolls over when you're climbing this route, it's a little unnerving. It is situated on the west face almost directly under the tracks.. I don't remember it being too spicy ( liberally bolted ).
content.location: Straight up the line of bolts on the west face of the south pillar.

content.description: This climb is the arete to the left of No Strings Attached. There is a ledge about 15 ft up that traverses across the south face of the south pillar. You start this climb on the east face and move up and left to access the ledge. Take a breather before you move straight up the outside corner. This climb is a little spicy near the top. There are small metal pieces that stick out of the mortar and stone that you can hook with a wired stopper if you feel the need to hang on the rope between the bolts. That's how I bolted this climb on lead. Don't think I would want to whip on them though. Definitely an exciting climb.
content.protection: All bolts. Maybe bring some wired stoppers with the wire looped out a little from the metal stopper, just in case. No anchor so traverse to the rap bolts on No Strings just a few feet to the right.
content.location: Starts on the east face of the south pillar and heads up and left to the outside corner.

content.description: This climbed can be accessed from either the east corner ( Thriller on the Pillar) or from the west corner ( Anglers Arete ). It basically starts from the ledge and wanders up the south face of the south pillar following the line of bolts. One of the hangers spin and Keith is an avid fisherman, hence the name.
content.protection: All bolts. Not sure about an anchor but you really don't want to rap this route since it is right over the water. You should either rappel off the east or west side of the pillar.
content.location: Normally we started this route on the west corner ( same as Anglers Arete ) and traversed on the ledge to the right. Probably could start on the opposite corner.

content.description: mantle to the ledge and climb the left bolt line w/ arete off. tricky moves, wanders across the left half of the face and uses the only 2 finger pocket on the pillar up high.   it looks like it has bolts,  but one of the bolts for that arete (iron ring) is around the corner, so it would be a very runout sketchy lead.  its a cool climb though so TR it from Iron ring or hang a directional from James brownstone. anchors are far enough apart that alpine draws (slings) may be appropriate

Start this climb down the hill on the east face of the north pillar and head up and right to just shy of the arete. You somewhat lay away the outside corner with your right hand all the way to the top. I believe Keith Hall went and bolted this climb, as with all the other routes on the north pillar, but never climbed it.
content.protection: Bolts. There is a rappel anchor on top of this pillar somewhere.
content.location: Starts on the east face of the north pillar and moves right and continues close to the edge of the arete.

content.description: This was the first established climb on these pillars. I do not know when or who put it up. It sits on the east face of the south pillar. It had homemade hangers. Not sure if it has been re-bolted. It is a very pumpy climb. It is best to access this climb during low water.
content.protection: All bolts. 1 cold shut and 2 rap hangars at the top of the route.  sketchy home,made hangars on the block on top of the pillar
content.location: The bolted line on the east face of the south pillar. Maybe homemade hangers on the bolts.

content.description: climb the downstream face left of the right arm eradicator past good bolts to a new anchor. small crimps. bad slopers. good climbing.  aretes off.  probably the hardest bolted climb in town

right bolt line on the island side face. mantle onto the ledge. uncomfortable first bolt if you cant reach from the ledge.  refreshingly diverse face climbing to new anchors. generally easier if you stay left/on the bolt line, but closer to 5.11 right of the bolts

mantle onto ledge then climb the N/E arete (downstream island side) mostly on the island face, past the giant iron bracket and several bolts, then onto the left face for a few moves and one bolt, then finish with one more bolt and anchors on the north face.
content.location: left arete and boltline on the face if you are looking towards the river from the island

content.description: A unique climb up the west face ( rt side) using only the metal pieces that stick out of the mortar and stone for pro. Kind of sketchy but there are ample places to loop a wired stopper throughout the climb. You probably don't want to take a leader fall but hanging on them should be ok. Hard to trust something that's been around since the civil war.
content.protection: Looped wired stoppers on small metal pieces. No anchor above this climb. Move a few feet to the left to find the rappel.
content.location: This climb is located on the right side of the west face of the north pillar.

content.description: this climb has the newest bolts. climb up under the bridge for a short romp up some dusty edges.  i know someone must have a name and FA for this, but i haven't dug it up
content.location: riverside face of the 1st pillar right under the train bridge.

content.description: A really nice casual climb up the outside corner of the west and north face of the north pillar. Pretty much the first climb you get to after surmounting the fence. This climb was or still is the most climbed route on Browns Island. You will need gear for the last piece of pro otherwise it’s mostly bolted.
content.protection: reasonable bolts. runout to anchors.  could protect with a thin hands size piece
content.location: This is the outside corner on the right side of the north face of the north pillar.

content.description: mantle onto the ledge and climb the arete clipping the james brownstone bolts. easier than brownstone until the crux finish. slightly easier if you move onto the face when it gets stout. also reachy. finish on shiny new anchors. as with brownstone, the first bolt is uncomfortably high if you cant reach from the ledge

This was my favorite climb in all of Richmond. Great position and moves straight up the outside corner. A little spicy at the top but it's all there. Move up and to the right, clipping a bolt before the ledge. Proceed up the arete and make sure you wave at the kayakers when they paddle by.
content.protection: All bolts. Anchor to climbers left.
content.location: This is the outside corner to the right of the west face on the south pillar.

content.description: These are the pillars on the north side of the James River opposite the Manchester Wall. The elevated train tracks split these pillars which are about 60ft tall. The north pillar climbs are easily accessed but the south pillar is partially in the river. Best to access those climbs during low water. You can climb in the shade or in the sun. You have to lead these climbs to gain the top anchors. It's been a good 15 yrs since I've climbed here so any input to the conditions of the bolts, anchors,etc would help. There is also climbs on the next smaller pillar out in the river. Since I put up most of these climbs I have no objection if someone updates the bolts and anchors.
